awd_titl_txt: Producing Conductive Polymer Composites by Placing Graphene at the Interfaces of the Blended Polymers
awd_abstract_narration:
Most conductive materials are made of metals but there is a special class of plastics, conductive polymer composites (CPCs), made from a mixture of polymer with conductive fillers. CPCs have the potential to exhibit unique mechanical and electronic properties but are challenging and expensive to manufacture. Currently, CPCs require a large amount of conductive fillers which greatly increases the cost of the materials and seriously degrades their mechanical strength, limiting implementation. This award will enable a new manufacturing method for CPCs through the selective placement of graphene, a highly conductive filler, in a polymer. By understanding how to locally control the filler placement, much less filler is needed, reducing both cost and the risk of degrading the strength of the composite material. The academic team has established connections with industry partners who recognize the potential impact of such a development.

This  research aims to create CPCs with desired properties via engineering the morphology of co-continuous polymer blends. The interface between two immiscible polymers of the co-continuous blends provides a percolating scaffold for graphene. The sparse percolating structure of the interface, as well as the large aspect ratio of graphene, will significantly reduce the amount of conductive fillers needed in CPCs and, therefore, cut the cost of manufacturing. Moreover, by choosing non-conductive yet mechanically strong polymers for the co-continuous blends, the approach can also greatly improve the mechanical properties of CPCs. The research will deliver scientific insight into the effect of the interfacial graphene on the morphology and properties of the CPCs.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
As one of the most widely used materials in the modern society, plastics have many advantages over other materials such as being lightweight, durable, flexible, easily moldable and inexpensive to produce. However, most plastics are electrically insulating, limiting their use for electronic applications.  Conductive polymer composites (CPCs) have been invented to overcome such a limit, which are commercially used in electrostatic discharge protection and electromagnetic interference shielding. The industrial production of CPCs relies on the melting compounding of conductive fillers (e.g. carbon black) into polymer matrices. The procedure requires a large quantity of the fillers in order to achieve an electric percolation, which seriously deteriorates the mechanical strength as well as the appearance of the composites. In this project, we explored a new way to make economically-viable CPCs with superior mechanical and electrical properties. Particularly, we utilized the cocontinuous structure of polymer blends, where the two polymers in the blends form two interpenetrating continuous networks, and then localized graphene sheets as conductive fillers at selected locations of the cocontinuous blends.

We adopted two specific approaches to make cocontinuous CPCs. In the first approach, we manufactured polymer/graphene composites with a cocontinuous structure via spinodal decomposition of two miscible polymers. Specifically, we selected a pair of mechanically robust polymers, poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) and poly(styrene-co-acrylonitrile) (SAN), which exhibit a lower critical solution temperature Tc. The polymer pair are miscible below Tc and phase separate above Tc. Thus, by first compounding PMMA, SAN, and graphene sheets together below Tc then inducing the phase separation of PMMA/SAN above Tc, we created spatially regular cocontinuous domains, where GNPs preferentially localized within the thermodynamically preferred SAN-rich phase and formed a conductive network. The method reduced the percolating filler concentration by half, giving rise to an electrical conductivity of 10‑8 S/cm at 1 wt% GNP loading.

To reduce the percolating filler concentration even further, we designed a second method, where we kinetically trap graphene sheets at the interface of cocontinuous polymer blends by controlling melt-compounding sequences and mixing times. As the method does not rely on the phase separation of miscible polymers and has a much lower restriction on the wetting properties of graphene sheets, this simple method can be adapted for a wide range of immiscible polymer systems. To demonstrate the broad applicability of the method, we have manufactured CPCs with two different immiscible polymer pairs: (i) polylactic acid (PLA) and polystyrene (PS); (ii) polylactide (PLA) and poly(ethylene-co-vinyl acetate) (EVA) . Using the method, we have created CPCs with a record low filler concentration of 0.048 wt%. We further showed that the CPCs made by such a method is stable against the processing flow of industrial productions.     

Our work has led to three publications in top journals in the field of polymer science and rheology, including one in Langmuir, one in Macromolecules, and one in Journal of Rheology. These recent publications have already accumulated a total 65 citations by the end of the grant. Our group has also given total 17 talks in conferences and seminars on the project, which disseminated the results of the project widely in the relevant academic and industrial communities. The grant supported two graduate students, both of whom have graduated with PhD and became research engineers in large chemical engineering and materials companies. Moreover, we have hosted three undergraduate students including one female student from the University of Minnesota in conducting the research of the project. Both PIs also actively participated in outreach programs during the period of the project. PI Cheng has volunteered in the science outreach programs at the Minnesota State Fair in 2017, 2018 and 2019 and at the Minnesota Science Museum in 2018. The co-PI Macosko has taught rheology short courses to industrial practitioners three times in 2019 and 2021 and gave lectures on polymer science to elementary school and high school students in 2017, 2018 and 2019.


Last Modified: 10/07/2021
Modified by: Xiang Cheng
